trial_identification.studytitle: Does vitamin D supplementation prevent progression of knee osteoarthritis? A randomised controlled trial
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effects of vitamin D supplementation on knee pain, knee structural change, and lower limb muscle strength in patients with symptomatic knee osteoarthritis: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial
trial_identification.trialacronym: VIDEO (The VItamin D Effect on Osteoarthritis) Study

interventions.interventions: Participants in the intervention arm will receive 50,000 IU (1.25 mg) cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) tablets given once monthly for 2 years
interventions.comparator: The control arm will receive an identical inert placebo (1.25 mg microcrystalline cellulose tablet).

primaryOutcome.outcome: Loss of knee cartilage volume, as assessed by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).
primaryOutcome.timepoint: MRI assessment will occur at month 0 (baseline) and 24.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: The progression of knee cartilage defects and enlargement of tibial bone area, as assessed by MRI;
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: MRI assessment will occur at month 0 (baseline) and 24.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Loss of lower limb muscle strength, measured by dynamometry;
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Muscle strength assessment will occur at month 0, 3, 6, 12 and 24.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Progress of knee pain, assessed by The Western Ontario & McMaster Universities Arthritis Index (WOMAC).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Knee pain assessment will occur at month 0, 3, 6, 12 and 24.

trial_design.concealment:
We will recruit subjects with symptomatic knee OA by using a combined strategy, including collaboration with general practitioners, specialist rheumatologists, and orthopaedic surgeons, as well as advertising through local media.
Allocation concealment will be ensured by the used of identical inert placebo, and the use of a central automated allocation procedure (consecutively numbered, sealed and opaque envelopes will be used), with security in place to ensure allocation data cannot be accessed or influenced by any person. Thus the randomized controlled trial (RCT) will be double blind.
trial_design.sequence: Allocation of participants will be based on computer generated random numbers.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Observational evidence suggests that vitamin D deficiency may have a role in the causes of osteoarthritis (OA) and there are biologically plausible mechanisms to explain this. There is, however, no evidence which shows that intervening with vitamin D supplementation can slow the progression of OA. This study will compare knee OA structural changes in patients receiving vitamin D supplementation with those receiving a placebo. Use of MRI will provide sensitive measures of knee OA changes.
